nodes.description: Why would humans want to swap spit for French kissing, which is open-mouthed, slippy-sloppy? The desire to lock lips is explained by science and psychology.

thumbnail.alternativeText: Why Do We Kiss With Tongues? The Science and Psychology of French Kissing

nodes.title: The science and psychology of French kissing

data.body:
## Why do we like [kissing](the-perfect-kiss-is-how-to-master-it)

 The face is sucking. A spit is swapped. French kissing is considered to be the most erotic style of kiss. It may sound kind of if you stop and think about it. . . It is repulsive. 80 million different types ofbacteria are swapped in one 10-second kiss, and the human mouth is home to perhaps 1,000 different types ofbacteria, according to scientists. Why would anyone want to eat someone else's tongue?

 French kissing is the only type of smooch that is reserved for lovers only, as the mouth is one of the body's main erogenous zones. A French kiss is an extremely popular way to express erotic passion and desire, even though from afar it might not sound like a good idea. A French kiss says "I like you so much I could eat you up!" or "I want you so close that you're inside of me."

 The boundary between you and your partner is blurred in a French kiss. Penetration, receptivity, vulnerability and assertion are involved. It's a simple way to find out if someone is compatible with another person. Below is a list of reasons why people like it.

## It feels good because of that

 Sheril Kirshenbaum, the author of The Science of Kissing: What Our Lips AreTelling Us, assumes you're wearing pants because your lips are your largest exposed erogenous zone. Some people have more nerve endings in their mouths than in their fingers, so they might get more pleasure from kissing than from other types of touching. The lips have one of the thinnest layers of skin on the body, and there is a huge concentration of nerve endings in them. It means for extra sensation.

 The release of hormones in the brain that promote attachment, happiness, pleasure, relaxation, and bonding can be stimulated by kissing. A kiss has a long list of positive effects and relatively few negative ones.

 If the kiss is hard, soft, slippery, or penetrating, your brain will light up like a slot machine. According to Kirshenbaum, even the lightest stimulation on the lips can have an effect on the brain.

data.body:
## You get a lot of information about your partner

 A person with a French kiss can be a lot to learn about. A kiss can offer a glimpse into what your partner is really like, and it can speak a thousand words. Tasting another person's essence is like that. If there's any compatibility between you, the Annabelle French kiss can be a good test.

 You learn a lot from your partner's smell, touch and taste during a kiss. There are many different types of cells in the nose, skin, and tongue that make up the Annabelle French kiss. Not to mention the things your other body parts are doing during the kiss. The more types of receptors that are involved, along with the number of cells that are activated, all serve to increase and heighten the sensitivity achieved in a French kiss.

### There is a kiss test

 According to a study, females might be more inclined than males to use kissing as a means of assessing a mate's compatibility. A kiss can be a test for a lot of women.

### What can a kiss teach you?

## Kissing is a good thing for you

Kissing can be good for your health.

### The health of future generations can be promoted by kissing

 Kissing allows a couple to get close enough to smell each other, which some researchers have focused on. Some theorize that we use our sense of smell to sniff out the best biological partners since our scent is an indicator of our immune system. Our chances of producing offspring with different immune systems are increased by genotypic differentiation. You may be more attracted to people with different genes if you kiss them.

data.body:
## When you kiss, what happens to your body?

 You kissed someone you like during a deep, enthusiastic French kiss. . .

## Why do we refer to it as French kissing?

 The Oxford English Dictionary included the term "French kiss" in 1923, but it is not clear when or where it was first used. After World War II, French kissing became more popular, according to The Science of Kissing by Sheril Kirshenbaum.

 French women were more comfortable with open-mouthed kissing than their counterparts, which may have led to the adoption of the French kiss. The saying "While in France get the girls to kiss you" became a popular one.
